The source of the claim: The expert's verdict mentions that the claim was published on Facebook by a page called "AIMIM India" and shared more than 21,000 times. It also highlights that the claim was accompanied by a photo of MP Asaduddin Owaisi, who is associated with the All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen (AIMIM) political party in India.
Content analysis: The expert's verdict provides a translation of the Hindi-language text in the graphic accompanying the claim. It states that the graphic mentions the number of names of different groups inscribed on Delhi's India Gate, including Muslims, Sikhs, Other Backward Class (OBC), Dalits, Upper castes, and Sanghi. The expert's verdict points out that the claim falsely attributes the inscription of Muslim servicemen's names on India Gate.
Historical verification: The expert's verdict refers to the Commonwealth War Graves Commission (CWGC) to authenticate the claim. It states that the India Gate memorial is dedicated to 70,000 troops of British India who died between 1914 and 1921, with 13,300 Commonwealth servicemen commemorated by name on the memorial. This information contradicts the claim's assertion of 61,000 Muslim servicemen's names being inscribed on India Gate.
Previous fact: checking: The expert's verdict mentions that the claim was previously fact-checked by the Times of India newspaper. Although it doesn't provide specific details about the fact-check, it indicates that the claim has been scrutinized and likely debunked by another reputable source.
